attributes.title: COVID-19_NICE
attributes.description: The purpose of this research is to investigate how psychological factors (e.g., perceived risk, knowledge, beliefs) predict psychological, behavioral, and health outcomes in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

q1.value: Behavioral and Health Outcomes of COVID-19 Concerns

q2.value: Corey L. Cook, Jon Grahe, Kate Faasse, Marc Wolpoff, Joseph McFall, Matthew Schmolesky, Dana C. Leighton, Michael Andreychik

q3.value: The purpose of this research is to investigate how psychological factors (e.g., perceived risk, knowledge, beliefs) predict psychological, behavioral, and health outcomes in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

q4.value: The nature of this project is largely exploratory and will allow contributors to make independent a priori predictions regarding the nature of relationships prior to accessing the dataset. For example, one may predict that perceptions of risk predict increased social distancing behaviors, mediated through felt anxiety (though not through felt depression or loneliness).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Blinding is not necessary as there are no experimental conditions, and all data will be collected remotely via an anonymous survey link.

question.value: The study will rely on correlational and quasi-experimental designs, allowing researchers to test advanced regression models regarding the relationships between variables (e.g., moderation and mediation PROCESS models).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected via the Psi Chi Network for International Collaborative Exchange (NICE). As such data will be collected around the world by researchers of varying professional levels.

q13.value: Each contributing site will be encouraged to recruit a minimum of 100 participants. The survey has the potential to collect data from hundreds to thousands of participants around the world. Such diverse data collection will allow us to test for patterns among an array of variables, including world region, specific location, culture, etc.

q14.value: For correlational analyses a sample size of >100 is preferred for optimal power. Data collection of at least 50 participants per site will allow adequate power to observe medium to large per site, and small effects when sites are combined.

q15.value: Data collection will continue during an "open registration" period in which labs from around the world may choose to participate. Each respective site may choose to stop data collection after acquiring >100 participants.

question.value: No variables will be manipulated. Demographic variables and variables related to knowledge of or concern for Coronavirus will be treated as predictors/quasi-experimental variables.
Measured Variables will include knowledge of COVID-19, information sources for the virus, perceived risk, avoidance behaviors, and mental health outcomes.

Regression models will be used to test independent hypotheses. For example, the hypothesis that perceptions of risk predict increased social distancing behaviors, mediated through felt anxiety (though not through felt depression or loneliness) would be tested with a parallel multiple mediation model using the PROCESS Macros.  Data collected from different world regions, affected differently by the virus, will be compared to determine whether virus severity influences behavioral and health outcomes.

q21.value: Regression coefficients, p values, and confidence intervals will be the primary inference criteria employed in statistical tests.

q24.value: Because of the novel and pressing nature of COVID-19 many of the analyses will be exploratory in nature. The virus and its global effects are unprecedented and measuring the effects of the pandemic will inform prevention and treatment strategies to such instances.

q2.value: Sean Webeck | Sean Nicholson-Crotty | Jill Nicholson-Crotty

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Study 1: What role does the perception of a rule's functionality play in understanding administrative burdens (i.e., Red Tape)? To what extent can explanations of administrative burdens moderate the way individuals perceive those burdens? A long line of research suggests that individuals perceive administrative burdens in a negative light. In this project we seek to understand what happens to the perception of administrative burdens when the role of those burdens are explained to a survey respondent. Study 2: Are certain administrative burdens less cumbersome than others? Does a preference for a certain type of performance metric influence the way individuals process that information? Study 3: Can the need to justify a performance assessment influence the way respondents process the performance information they will see?

q16.value: (See pre-analysis plan for more in-depth description of hypotheses.) 1. Individuals who see a prompt about a public value will perceive less administrative burden when performing tasks. 2. Individuals who are told to justify a performance assessment will perceive less administrative burden. 3. Individuals who see a public value will interpret less administrative burden in their workplace. 4. Individuals who see a preferred performance metric will be more willing to engage in System 1 processing. 5. Individuals who exhibit System 1 processing when assessing performance information will still be able to accurately recall the objective performance metric they saw.

q17.value: We will use ANOVA and other post-hoc assessment techniques to determine any differences in the assessed performance of individuals randomly assigned to different treatment groups.

attributes.title: Carpet Negotiation
attributes.description: How do maximal and minimal goal standards influence satisfaction and decisions after feedback about goal-performance discrepancies? In this study, we extend our previous research on the effects of satisfaction with the performance results by looking at the behavioral consequences (i.e., decision making). The study is a simulated negotiation game.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: Based on a pilot study, we made calculations with G-power (effect size: 0.15; ∝ error probability: 0.05; power (1-β error probability): 0.80; number of groups: 4, numerator df = 1). The desired sample size would be 351 participants. Given that we have to expect some exclusions of participants. We aim for collecting 600 participants.

analyses.value:
We will run a 2 x 2 x 2 ANOVA on task satisfaction. 
The main effect of goal standard tests Hypothesis 1. 
For Hypothesis 2, we expect a 3-way interaction effect. Under failure, we expect that the simple effect of achievement level on satisfaction will be smaller in the minimal compared to the maximal goal condition. In contrast, under success, we expect that the simple effect of achievement level on satisfaction will be smaller in the maximal compared to the minimal goal condition. We thus, will test for simple interaction effects within the performance conditions and simple main effects within the performance/goal standard conditions. However, for the test of the hypothesis, we take the three-way interaction effect and the pattern of results as described as supporting evidence.
To test Hypothesis 3, we run a logistic regression predicting decision with satisfaction. 
TO test hypothesis 4, we run a mediated moderation analysis using the process macro in SPSS (Hayes, 2017). We use model 11 in the process macro with Y = decision; X = achievement level; M = satisfaction; W = MinMax; Z = Perform. We test for the moderated mediation effect. The test of H2 is part of the calculation in the first step regression predicting the mediator. Thus, this step of the moderated mediation testing is already provided with the test of Hypothesis 2. In the second step, the dependent variable (decision) is predicted by achievement level and satisfaction in a logistic regression. Here, we expect a significant effect of satisfaction controlling for achievement level. Finally, we test the moderated mediation as with the index of moderated moderated mediation (a statistic providing information of the overall model). We additionally will report the conditional moderated mediation within the performance conditions. In other words, how the interaction of goal standards and achievement level predicts decision via satisfaction within failure and success. We also report the mediation effects per performance/goal standard conditions (4 effects). These additional statistic are only meant to help interpreting the results of this complex moderated mediation better.

outliers.value:
We will run the analysis based on different exclusion criteria. 

We have included a fair attention check when we manipulate goal standard. More precisely, we ask: “Based on the text above, what is the minimal/ideal selling price you should achieve (type in the exact number as stated above in pounds)?“. We exclude all participants who will not type “500” before we run our analysis. 
At the end of the survey, we have two further attention checks. In our previous (partly registered) studies, we used these as exclusion criteria. However, meanwhile we have acknowledged that some literature points to the fact that such attention checks might be seen as not fair (Prolific Team, 12th Sep 2018) and might reduce data quality (Vannette, 2017). However, given that we have used such a procedure in our previous studies, we run this secondary analysis excluding these participants (in addition to the ones who failed the fair attention check) to provide a comparison with the results of our previous studies. There will be one attention check for goal standard (maximal/minimal) asking participants to make a choice between 4 conditions about the set goal: The client asked to sell the carpet for at least 500 Pounds; The client asked to sell the carpet for ideally 500 Pounds; The client asked to sell the carpet for at least 400 Pounds; The client asked to sell the carpet for ideally 400 Pounds (the last two answers have the wrong target goal; the correct answer for the first two depends on the goal standard condition). The other attention check is about the buyer offer and also has 4 choices: 420, 490, 510, and 580. The correct answer depends on the performance and achievement level conditions.
As we will use prolific academic for the data collection, we will make use of their pre-screening. We will include participants who (1) have English as first language, (2) have an approval rate of 90% or higher and (3) have not taken part in one of our previous studies on this topic within the last two years.


Vannette, D. (2017). Using attention checks in your surveys may harm data quality. Retrieved from https://www.qualtrics.com/blog/using-attention-checks-in-your-surveys-may-harm-data-quality/

Prolific Team (12th Sep 2018). Using attention checks as a measure of data quality. Retrieved on 30th March 2020 at https://researcher-help.prolific.co/hc/en-gb/articles/360009223553-Using-attention-checks-as-a-measure-of-data-quality

dependent.value: Task satisfaction: Participants will be asked to rate how satisfied they are with the offer. The scale ranges from 1 to 9 with smilies on top of the scale. Higher values represent more satisfaction. Second, we ask whether they would agree to the buyer offer: yes/no.

conditions.value:
We have 8 conditions in a 2 (goal standard: maximal versus minimal) by 2 (performance: success versus failure) by 2 (achievement level: low versus high) between subject design. 
Participants will be randomly placed in one of the 8 conditions.

hypothesis.value:
How do maximal and minimal goal standards influence satisfaction and decisions after feedback about goal-performance discrepancies? In this study, we extend our previous research on the effects of satisfaction with the performance results by looking at the behavioral consequences (i.e., decision making). The study is a simulated negotiation game.  
We manipulate goal standard (maximal versus minimal), performance (success versus failure) and achievement level (low versus high) as between-subject factors. (Note that a low achievement level in the success condition means a performance above the goal but less distant from the goal than a high achievement level; in contrast, a low achievement level in the failure condition implies a higher distance to the goal compared to a high achievement level).
We ask participants to participate in a negotiation simulation about a carpet trade. We tell them that they either will be placed in the role of seller or buyer. Actually, all participants are placed in a seller role. After questions about demographics (age, gender), we ostensibly match them up with another participant - to make the ostensible interactive nature of the negotiation more believable, we also state that if they cannot be matched they will be provided with a simple scenario. In reality, all participants are ostensibly matched after 17 seconds (this time-choice is based on a) it should take some time to match b) not too much time because it is an online study). 
As said, all participants are place in the seller role. Here, we manipulated first the goal standard. We tell them that their task is to sell a carpet for a client. The antique carpet (we provide a picture) seemingly has elicited some interest form a potential buyer abroad. The participant (seller) should sell the carpet for at least (minimal)/ for ideally (maximal) 500 Pounds. Afterwards, we include a fair attention check (Prolific Team, 12th Sep 2018).

Next, the ostensible byer will make her/his first offer. Here, we manipulated performance (failure vs success) and achievement level (low versus high): 420 Pounds (failure/low achievement), 490 Pounds (failure/ high achievement), 510 Pounds (success/ low achievement), 580 Pounds (success/high achievement). Afterwards we ask for the satisfaction level on a scale from 1 to 9 ) with smilies above). Next, we ask whether they accept the offer (yes vs no).

Hypothesis 1: Overall, task satisfaction levels will be higher within maximal goal condition compared to the minimal goal condition. 
Hypothesis 2: Goal standards, performance, and level of achievement have a three-way interaction effect on the level of task satisfaction such that:
In the case of failure, the level of achievement has less impact on task satisfaction when a minimal (vs. maximal) goal standard is used as the reference point.
In the case of success, the level of achievement has less impact on task satisfaction when a maximal (vs. minimal) goal standard is used as the reference point. 
Hypothesis 3: We predict that task satisfaction levels will relate positively to the decision to agree to the negotiation offer.
Hypothesis 4: We predict a moderated mediation in the way that the three-way interaction predicted in Hypothesis 2 will have an effect on the decision to agree to the negotiation offer via task satisfaction. 

Prolific Team (12th Sep 2018). Using attention checks as a measure of data quality. Retrieved on 30th March 2020 at https://researcher-help.prolific.co/hc/en-gb/articles/360009223553-Using-attention-checks-as-a-measure-of-data-quality

However, for the test of the hypothesis, we take the three-way interaction effect and the pattern of results as described as supporting evidence.

In the second step, the dependent variable (decision) is predicted by achievement level and satisfaction in a logistic regression. Here, we expect a significant effect of satisfaction controlling for achievement level. Finally, we test the moderated mediation as with the index of moderated moderated mediation (a statistic providing information of the overall model). In other words, how the interaction of goal standards and achievement level predicts decision via satisfaction within failure and success. We also report the mediation effects per performance/goal standard conditions (4 effects). attributes.title: Negative life experiences and religiosity
attributes.description: This survey includes sociodemographic measures, a negative life experiences inventory, measures of negative affective traits, life satisfaction, existential security, death anxiety, religious belief, religious behaviour, God concepts and religious locus of control. Data was collected from the USA, Brazil, China, India, Indonesia, Russia, Thailand, and Turkey.

summary.value: This is not a pre-registration. Rather, it is to create a permanent, frozen record of the data, scripts, codebooks, and other files associated with this project.

registration_responses.summary: This is not a pre-registration. Rather, it is to create a permanent, frozen record of the data, scripts, codebooks, and other files associated with this project.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

attributes.title: Rasch model of the Mental Rotation Test administered online

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

attributes.title: Study 1b -  What makes  a life meaningful? Final version
attributes.description: The main objective of this study is to investigate which features impact laypeople's intuitions about the "meaningfulness" of lives.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: What makes a life meaningful? Morality, effort, or life direction?

other.value: We will explore to which extent personality (as measured by the Ten Item Personality Measure; Gosling & al. 2013) and the subjective meaning participants give to their own life (as measured by Meaningful Life Questionnaire; Steger & al. 2006) moderate the effect of our different factors on meaningfulness, happiness and enviable lives ratings. To this end, we will use three generalized linear models.

sample.value: After our pretest, we decided that we wanted to detect a change of R² = 0.03 in a multiple regression analysis with a power of .80 and an α-level of 5%. After performing the power analysis, we have decided to recruit 300 participants on Amazon Mechanical Turk.

analyses.value:
First part: rating vignettes
For the study we will perform the following analysis: 
Dependent measures scores from Likert scales questions will be analyzed through three mixed ANOVAS:
Anova 1 will test the effect of the three factors of our study i.e. (life direction, efforts, morality) on people’s intuitions about the meaning of life.
Anova 2 will test the effect of the three factors of our study i.e. (life direction, efforts, morality) on people’s intuitions about the happiness of life.
Anova 3 will test the effect of the three factors of our study i.e. (life direction, efforts, morality) on people’s intuitions about the enviableness of life. 
Furthermore, in order to calculate how much of the variance of three of the dependent variables (meaningfulness, happiness and enviable life) can be explained by our factors, we will perform a multiple linear regression between the score of meaningfulness, life direction, efforts and morality as well as between the score happiness, enviable life and the score of life direction, efforts and morality. 
Finally, to test the secondary hypothesis, we will calculate the mean score of happiness, meaningfulness and enviable life for each vignette and calculate the correlation between these scores among each of the sixteen vignettes. 

Second part: ranking vignettes
The interaction prediction derived from the hypotheses will be tested by using a
Friedman test.

outliers.value: People who won't correctly answer the exclusion question as well the validation questions will be excluded from the data.

dependent.value:
In the first part of the experiment, after each vignette, participants will be asked to answer several questions. The dependent variables are:

Participants’ judgments about the meaningfulness, happiness and the enviableness of the particular life described in the vignette (numeric variable): these judgments will be measured through a seven points Lickert scale.
“To what extent does this person have a happy life?”
“To what extent does this person have a life that is meaningful?”
“To what extent does this person have an enviable life?”

The subject’s judgments about the good or bad start of the beggining of the life, the efforts made through life, the morality and to what extent the character is able to live comfortably at the end of the story (numeric variable): these will be measured through a seven points Lickert scale.
“How much do you agree with the following statement "the character had a good start in life"?”
“How much do you agree with the following statement "the character is a hard worker"?”
“How much do you agree with the following statement "the character is a good person"?“  
“How much do you agree with the following statement "the character was able to live comfortably at the end of the story"?”

In the second part of the experiments, after participants have read the four stories, they will have to rank them from the most meaningful to the least, and also from the happiest to the least (ordinal variable).

conditions.value:
The experimental design is in two different parts, a rating one and a ranking one. 

First part: rating vignettes

There are four conditions in which participants are randomly assigned.

Each participant has to read four vignettes from a pool of sixteen (for the story see the stimulus bank section). 
All vignettes participants will have to read is about the life of different characters and is composed of three different factors.
A factor named « life direction », composed of two variables: the character either could start with privileges (i.e. cultivated and financially comfortable parents) or the opposite (i.e. uneducated and poor parents), and either end her life in a comfortable situation or an uncomfortable and stressful situation. Which leads to four possibilities (Life Direction ++, +-, -+, --)
A factor named « morality »: the character either could be an altruist and selfless person or a mean and selfish one. Which leads to two possibilities (Morality +, -).
Another one named « Effort »: the character either could be a hard-worker or a lazy person. Which leads to two possibilities (Effort +, -).

Mixing all these different factors leads to 4 * 2 * 2 vignettes  ( for example, LD ++ M + E +,  LD +-, M -, E + and so on).

Each vignette is built this way :
(a) Life direction (beginning)
(b) Effort.
(c) Morality (first part).
(a) Life direction (ending).
(c) Morality (last part, in order to show that the character was not only moral or immoral at the beginning of the story but also at the end).

The vignette doesn’t provide many details to avoid all possible confounding variables. 

The design is mixed (although the sample collected is independent). Each participant will be subject to each variation of the life direction factor i.e. ++, +-, -+, -- (within-subject) - , however, the morality and effort will be randomized, although they will stay stable across the four directions (between-subject). For example, a participant could read four vignettes with a hard worker but not moral character for every life direction possible, or someone who is a hard worker and moral for every life direction possible.  

Second part: ranking life’s characters. 

There are four conditions to which participants are randomly assigned. In each conditions participants have to read four stories in which three different factors are varied: 
A factor named « life direction », composed of two variables: the character either could start with privileges (i.e. cultivated and financially comfortable parents) or the opposite (i.e. uneducated and poor parents), and either end her life in a comfortable situation or an uncomfortable and stressful situation. Which leads to four possibilities (Life Direction ++, +-, -+, --)
A factor named « morality »: the character either could be an altruist and selfless person or a mean and selfish one. Which leads to two possibilities (Morality +, -).
Another one named « Effort »: the character either could be a hard-worker or a lazy person. Which leads to two possibilities (Effort +, -).
In each condition the factor morality and effort of the four stories were the same, only the life direction was different. Then participants have to rank these lives from the most meaningful to the least, the happier to the least and those who have the best life from those who have the worse. 
All the stories are built this way but are slightly different from the first part of the experiment (see the stimuli bank for more details) :
(a) Life direction (beginning)
(b) Effort.
(c) Morality (first part).
(a) Life direction (ending).
(c) Morality (last part, in order to show that the character was not only moral or immoral at the beginning of the story but also at the end).

hypothesis.value:
The main objective of this study is to investigate which features impact laypeople's intuitions about the "meaningfulness" of lives.

We hypothesize that the manipulation of three different factors (life direction, efforts and morality) in vignettes (which content is about the life history of a character) will lead to a variation in participants’ judgments about how happy and meaningful the life of the character is and that there is a specific hierarchy between all these stories i.e. that people will rank them from the most meaningful to the least meaningful/most happy to the least happy in a specific way.
We also formulate a secondary hypothesis i.e. there won't have a strong correlation between the rating of the happiness and meaningfulness from the story of the characters in the vignettes (i.e. r ≤ 0.5).

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: What makes a life meaningful? Morality, effort, or life direction?
registration_responses.other: We will explore to which extent personality (as measured by the Ten Item Personality Measure; Gosling & al. 2013) and the subjective meaning participants give to their own life (as measured by Meaningful Life Questionnaire; Steger & al. 2006) moderate the effect of our different factors on meaningfulness, happiness and enviable lives ratings. To this end, we will use three generalized linear models.
registration_responses.sample: After our pretest, we decided that we wanted to detect a change of R² = 0.03 in a multiple regression analysis with a power of .80 and an α-level of 5%. After performing the power analysis, we have decided to recruit 300 participants on Amazon Mechanical Turk.
registration_responses.analyses:
First part: rating vignettes
For the study we will perform the following analysis: 
Dependent measures scores from Likert scales questions will be analyzed through three mixed ANOVAS:
Anova 1 will test the effect of the three factors of our study i.e. (life direction, efforts, morality) on people’s intuitions about the meaning of life.
Anova 2 will test the effect of the three factors of our study i.e. (life direction, efforts, morality) on people’s intuitions about the happiness of life.
Anova 3 will test the effect of the three factors of our study i.e. (life direction, efforts, morality) on people’s intuitions about the enviableness of life. 
Furthermore, in order to calculate how much of the variance of three of the dependent variables (meaningfulness, happiness and enviable life) can be explained by our factors, we will perform a multiple linear regression between the score of meaningfulness, life direction, efforts and morality as well as between the score happiness, enviable life and the score of life direction, efforts and morality. 
Finally, to test the secondary hypothesis, we will calculate the mean score of happiness, meaningfulness and enviable life for each vignette and calculate the correlation between these scores among each of the sixteen vignettes. 

Second part: ranking vignettes
The interaction prediction derived from the hypotheses will be tested by using a
Friedman test.
registration_responses.outliers: People who won't correctly answer the exclusion question as well the validation questions will be excluded from the data.
registration_responses.dependent:
In the first part of the experiment, after each vignette, participants will be asked to answer several questions. The dependent variables are:

Participants’ judgments about the meaningfulness, happiness and the enviableness of the particular life described in the vignette (numeric variable): these judgments will be measured through a seven points Lickert scale.
“To what extent does this person have a happy life?”
“To what extent does this person have a life that is meaningful?”
“To what extent does this person have an enviable life?”

The subject’s judgments about the good or bad start of the beggining of the life, the efforts made through life, the morality and to what extent the character is able to live comfortably at the end of the story (numeric variable): these will be measured through a seven points Lickert scale.
“How much do you agree with the following statement "the character had a good start in life"?”
“How much do you agree with the following statement "the character is a hard worker"?”
“How much do you agree with the following statement "the character is a good person"?“  
“How much do you agree with the following statement "the character was able to live comfortably at the end of the story"?”

In the second part of the experiments, after participants have read the four stories, they will have to rank them from the most meaningful to the least, and also from the happiest to the least (ordinal variable).
registration_responses.conditions:
The experimental design is in two different parts, a rating one and a ranking one. 

First part: rating vignettes

There are four conditions in which participants are randomly assigned.

Each participant has to read four vignettes from a pool of sixteen (for the story see the stimulus bank section). 
All vignettes participants will have to read is about the life of different characters and is composed of three different factors.
A factor named « life direction », composed of two variables: the character either could start with privileges (i.e. cultivated and financially comfortable parents) or the opposite (i.e. uneducated and poor parents), and either end her life in a comfortable situation or an uncomfortable and stressful situation. Which leads to four possibilities (Life Direction ++, +-, -+, --)
A factor named « morality »: the character either could be an altruist and selfless person or a mean and selfish one. Which leads to two possibilities (Morality +, -).
Another one named « Effort »: the character either could be a hard-worker or a lazy person. Which leads to two possibilities (Effort +, -).

Mixing all these different factors leads to 4 * 2 * 2 vignettes  ( for example, LD ++ M + E +,  LD +-, M -, E + and so on).

Each vignette is built this way :
(a) Life direction (beginning)
(b) Effort.
(c) Morality (first part).
(a) Life direction (ending).
(c) Morality (last part, in order to show that the character was not only moral or immoral at the beginning of the story but also at the end).

The vignette doesn’t provide many details to avoid all possible confounding variables. 

The design is mixed (although the sample collected is independent). Each participant will be subject to each variation of the life direction factor i.e. ++, +-, -+, -- (within-subject) - , however, the morality and effort will be randomized, although they will stay stable across the four directions (between-subject). For example, a participant could read four vignettes with a hard worker but not moral character for every life direction possible, or someone who is a hard worker and moral for every life direction possible.  

Second part: ranking life’s characters. 

There are four conditions to which participants are randomly assigned. In each conditions participants have to read four stories in which three different factors are varied: 
A factor named « life direction », composed of two variables: the character either could start with privileges (i.e. cultivated and financially comfortable parents) or the opposite (i.e. uneducated and poor parents), and either end her life in a comfortable situation or an uncomfortable and stressful situation. Which leads to four possibilities (Life Direction ++, +-, -+, --)
A factor named « morality »: the character either could be an altruist and selfless person or a mean and selfish one. Which leads to two possibilities (Morality +, -).
Another one named « Effort »: the character either could be a hard-worker or a lazy person. Which leads to two possibilities (Effort +, -).
In each condition the factor morality and effort of the four stories were the same, only the life direction was different. Then participants have to rank these lives from the most meaningful to the least, the happier to the least and those who have the best life from those who have the worse. 
All the stories are built this way but are slightly different from the first part of the experiment (see the stimuli bank for more details) :
(a) Life direction (beginning)
(b) Effort.
(c) Morality (first part).
(a) Life direction (ending).
(c) Morality (last part, in order to show that the character was not only moral or immoral at the beginning of the story but also at the end).

We hypothesize that the manipulation of three different factors (life direction, efforts and morality) in vignettes (which content is about the life history of a character) will lead to a variation in participants’ judgments about how happy and meaningful the life of the character is and that there is a specific hierarchy between all these stories i.e. that people will rank them from the most meaningful to the least meaningful/most happy to the least happy in a specific way.

attributes.title: Physical functioning limitations and physical activity of people experiencing homelessness: A review
attributes.description: This review will comprehensively evaluate physical functioning and physical activity in people experiencing homelessness

summary.value: This registers the review 'Physical functioning limitations and physical activity of people experiencing homelessness: A Review' .

registration_responses.summary: This registers the review 'Physical functioning limitations and physical activity of people experiencing homelessness: A Review' .

attributes.title: Pneumococcal carriage and antibiotic susceptibility patterns in mother-baby pairs in a rural community in Eastern Uganda: a cross-sectional study
attributes.description: This study aimed to estimate pneumococcal carriage and determine antibiotic susceptibility patterns of the pneumococci isolated from mother-baby pairs in Ngora district after the rollout of the pneumococcal vaccine. We hypothesized that high carriage of Streptococcus pneumoniae in mothers leads to carriage in their babies and hence a greater chance of contracting pneumonia.
tags: Busitema University Faculty of Health Sciences

q1.value: Gabriel Madut Akech, Mercy Naloli, Paul Sebwami, Patrick Kazibwe, Maureen Atwikiriize, Julius Onyait, Paul Oboth, Julius Nteziyaremye, REBECCA NEKAKA, Iramiot Jacob Stanley

q2.value:
1.Pneumococcal carriage in a mother leads to pneumococcal carriage in a baby
2. low coverage of the PCV10 vaccine leads to a high prevalence of pneumococcal carriage in babies less than 5 years old.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A cross-sectional study was carried out in Ngora district Health Centre IV and Ngora HC IV catchment area from 7th April to 5th May 2018. Children under five years old and their mothers were selected in a ‘mother-baby pair’ to determine the relationship between carriage of pneumococci in the baby, prevalence of pneumococci in mothers and the child’s immunization status. The inclusion criteria were mother –baby pairs from selected villages in the community, and those who visited Ngora Health Center IV for routine immunization with babies under the age of five years.  For this study, we defined a baby as any person under the age of five years and a mother was considered as either biological or any other female in direct care of the baby for atleast four weeks. This was aimed at comparing samples from the baby, and the person in closest contact with the baby for the longest duration of time in the most recent past to allow presumed cross transmission/cross infection. Exclusion criteria were babies above five years, and those presented by male care takers as those were presumed to spend less time with the babies as is the general practice. Mothers who did not consent, or opted out at any stage of the research were excluded as well. The purpose of the research was explained to the mothers and they were asked to voluntarily participate in the research. Demographic data was captured using a pretest questionnaire. The questionnaire was pre-tested with 10 mother-baby pairs at Mbale regional referral hospital Young Child Clinic (YCC) because the mother-baby pair in Mbale hospital had homogenous characteristics with our target population in Ngora district. After pre-testing of the questionnaires, some questions were rephrased for clarity. Consecutive sampling was used to recruit participants meeting the criteria of inclusion at the young child clinic and in randomly selected villages in the community until the required sample size was achieved. This method is relatively easy to employ and reduces the chances for intentional and unintentional manipulation by staff, or errors due to confusion. A total of 152 mother-baby pairs fulfilling the inclusion criteria were sampled

q8.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: Children under five years old and their mothers were selected in a ‘mother-baby pair’ to determine the relationship between carriage of pneumococci in the baby, the prevalence of pneumococci in mothers and the child’s immunization status. The inclusion criteria were mother-baby pairs from selected villages in the community, and those who visited Ngora Health Center IV for routine immunization with babies under the age of five years.  For this study, we defined a baby as any person under the age of five years and a mother was considered as either biological or any other female in the direct care of the baby for at least four weeks. This was aimed at comparing samples from the baby, and the person in closest contact with the baby for the longest duration of time in the most recent past to allow presumed cross-transmission/cross-infection. Exclusion criteria were babies above five years, and those presented by male care takers as those were presumed to spend less time with the babies as is the general practice. Mothers who did not consent, or opted out at any stage of the research were excluded as well. The purpose of the research was explained to the mothers and they were asked to voluntarily participate in the research. Demographic data was captured using a pretest questionnaire. The questionnaire was pre-tested with 10 mother-baby pairs at Mbale regional referral hospital Young Child Clinic (YCC) because the mother-baby pair in Mbale hospital had homogenous characteristics with our target population in Ngora district. After pre-testing of the questionnaires, some questions were rephrased for clarity. Consecutive sampling was used to recruit participants meeting the criteria of inclusion at the young child clinic and in randomly selected villages in the community until the required sample size was achieved. This method is relatively easy to employ and reduces the chances for intentional and unintentional manipulation by staff, or errors due to confusion.

q11.value:
A total of 152 mother-baby pairs fulfilling the inclusion criteria were sampled. The sample size was estimated using the Kish and Leslie formula developed in 1965. 
N= (z^2 (pq) )/e^2 
N= Sample size. 
Z= confidence level at 95 % (standard value of 1.96). 
P= estimated prevalence of pneumonia in Uganda (27.2%) (11).
q=1-p (72.8%)
e= margin of error at 5%.
N=(〖1.96〗^2 (0.272×0.728))/〖(0.05)〗^2     
N=304
Specimen collection and transport 
Nasal pharyngeal specimens were collected from the posterior nasopharynx of the mother and the baby using sterile cotton swab sticks moistened with 0.9% physiological saline. The sample collection was at the young child clinic in Ngora Health Centre IV and the selected villages in the community by qualified hospital laboratory technicians. Separate swabs were used to collect samples from a mother and a baby in a mother-baby pair. To prevent sample contamination, the swab was placed in a casing containing Amies transport medium and immediately placed into a cool box containing ice packs for transportation to Busitema University Microbiology laboratory for culture and susceptibility testing within 12 hours.

question.value: The major variables collected were age, sex, immunization status, PCV10 vaccination and carriage of pneumococci
